abstract.p: Dr Alfred Lewy, expert on resetting biological clocks, proposes system for speeding peoples' bodies readjustment to going off daylight savings time (S)

block.p: When Americans go off daylight time at 2 A.M. on Sunday, they will need to set their clocks -- and their bodies -- back an hour.

To the rescue, Dr. Alfred Lewy, an expert on resetting biological clocks and a professor at Oregon Health Sciences University in Portland. Six months ago, Dr. Lewy proposed a system for speeding the adjustment to daylight time. Now, he has a regimen to help people shift their body clocks the other way, relying on the body's two main time keepers: sunlight and the hormone melatonin, produced by a tiny gland at night.
When Americans go off daylight time at 2 A.M. on Sunday, they will need to set their clocks -- and their bodies -- back an hour.

To the rescue, Dr. Alfred Lewy, an expert on resetting biological clocks and a professor at Oregon Health Sciences University in Portland. Six months ago, Dr. Lewy proposed a system for speeding the adjustment to daylight time. Now, he has a regimen to help people shift their body clocks the other way, relying on the body's two main time keepers: sunlight and the hormone melatonin, produced by a tiny gland at night.

Dr. Lewy's prescription: First thing Saturday morning, take a tiny dose of melatonin -- between 0.1 and 0.5 milligrams (100 to 500 micrograms) and repeat that for the next two or three mornings. (Do not drive if the melatonin makes you sleepy.) On Sunday, avoid sunlight for the first hour of daylight by wearing dark sunglasses.
The shift back to standard time, Dr. Lewy says, is tougher than adjusting to daylight time because the earlier dawn is counterproductive to the needed change in body time.
